docs.title: Project Overview
docs.text: This project implements a complete MLOps pipeline for energy demand forecasting using machine learning.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Real-time Predictions: REST API for energy demand forecasting
  • Data Pipeline: Automated data ingestion and preprocessing
  • Model Training: Automated training with experiment tracking
  • Model Registry: Version control for ML models
  • Monitoring: Data drift and model performance monitoring
  • Deployment: Docker containers with Kubernetes-ready manifests

docs.title: Save as: test_api.py
docs.text:
import requests
import json

BASE_URL = "http://localhost:8000"

def test_health():
    """Test health endpoint"""
    print("\n=== Testing Health Check ===")
    response = requests.get(f"{BASE_URL}/health")
    print(f"Status: {response.status_code}")
    print(json.dumps(response.json(), indent=2))

def test_models():
    """Test models listing"""
    print("\n=== Testing Models List ===")
    response = requests.get(f"{BASE_URL}/models")
    print(f"Status: {response.status_code}")
    print(json.dumps(response.json(), indent=2))

def test_predict_lstm():
    """Test LSTM prediction"""
    print("\n=== Testing LSTM Prediction ===")
    payload = {
        "model_name": "lstm",
        "hours_ahead": 24,
        "data_path": "data/processed/processed_energy_weather.csv"
    }
    response = requests.post(f"{BASE_URL}/predict", json=payload)
    print(f"Status: {response.status_code}")
    if response.status_code == 200:
        result = response.json()
        print(f"Predictions: {len(result['predictions'])} values")
        print(f"First 5: {result['predictions'][:5]}")
    else:
        print(response.text)

def test_predict_prophet():
    """Test Prophet prediction"""
    print("\n=== Testing Prophet Prediction ===")
    payload = {
        "model_name": "prophet",
        "hours_ahead": 48,
        "data_path": "data/processed/processed_energy_weather.csv"
    }
    response = requests.post(f"{BASE_URL}/predict", json=payload)
    print(f"Status: {response.status_code}")
    if response.status_code == 200:
        result = response.json()
        print(f"Predictions: {len(result['predictions'])} values")
    else:
        print(response.text)

def test_ensemble():
    """Test ensemble prediction"""
    print("\n=== Testing Ensemble Prediction ===")
    payload = {
        "hours_ahead": 24,
        "data_path": "data/processed/processed_energy_weather.csv"
    }
    response = requests.post(f"{BASE_URL}/ensemble-predict", json=payload)
    print(f"Status: {response.status_code}")
    if response.status_code == 200:
        result = response.json()
        print(f"Models used: {result['metadata']['models_used']}")
        print(f"Predictions: {len(result['predictions'])} values")
    else:
        print(response.text)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    print("Starting API Tests...")
    print("Make sure API is running: python src/deployment/fastapi_app.py")

    try:
        test_health()
        test_models()
        test_predict_lstm()
        test_predict_prophet()
        test_ensemble()
        print("\n=== All Tests Complete ===")
    except requests.exceptions.ConnectionError:
        print("\n[ERROR] Cannot connect to API. Is it running?")
        print("Start with: python src/deployment/fastapi_app.py")

docs.title: Model Deployment Guide - MLOps Best Practices
Overview
docs.text: This guide follows senior ML engineering practices for model versioning, deployment, and lifecycle management.

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
models/
├── production/          # Production-ready models (API loads from here)
├── staging/            # Models under testing
├── archived/           # Previous versions
└── [root]             # Training output (staging area)

docs.title: Time Series Models
docs.text:
1. LSTM - Deep learning forecasting
  2. Files: lstm_model_lstm.h5, lstm_model_scaler.pkl
  3. Framework: TensorFlow/Keras

  4. Use Case: Complex pattern recognition

  5. Prophet - Seasonal forecasting

  6. Files: prophet_model_prophet.pkl
  7. Framework: Facebook Prophet

  8. Use Case: Trend and seasonality detection

  9. ARIMA - Statistical forecasting

  10. Files: arima_model_fitted.pkl, arima_model_params.pkl
  11. Framework: Statsmodels
  12. Use Case: Classical time series analysis

docs.title: Gradient Boosting Models
docs.text:
1. LightGBM - Feature-based forecasting
  2. Files: lightgbm_gbm_model.joblib, lightgbm_gbm_model_feature_engineer.joblib
  3. Framework: LightGBM

  4. Use Case: Fast, efficient predictions with engineered features

  5. XGBoost - Feature-based forecasting

  6. Files: xgboost_gbm_model.joblib, xgboost_gbm_model_feature_engineer.joblib
  7. Framework: XGBoost
  8. Use Case: High-accuracy predictions with feature engineering

docs.title: 1. MLOps Pipeline
docs.text:
• DVC for data/model versioning was essential
  • MLflow provided excellent experiment tracking
  • Prefect simplified workflow orchestration

docs.title: 2. Model Development
docs.text:
• Starting with XGBoost as baseline was the right choice
  • Feature engineering had the biggest impact on performance
  • Time series cross-validation was crucial for reliable metrics

docs.title: 3. Deployment
docs.text:
• Docker containers made deployment consistent
  • FastAPI provided excellent performance
  • Kubernetes scaling worked smoothly

docs.title: 4. Monitoring
docs.text:
• Early drift detection prevented model degradation
  • Grafana dashboards helped quickly identify issues

docs.title: Challenge 1: Data Quality Issues
docs.text:
Problem: 15% missing values in early data
Solution: Implemented automated data validation with Great Expectations
Result: Reduced to < 1% missing

docs.title: Challenge 2: Model Drift
docs.text:
Problem: Model performance degraded after 3 months
Solution: Automated retraining pipeline with drift triggers
Result: Maintained consistent 94% accuracy

docs.title: Challenge 3: API Latency
docs.text:
Problem: Initial API response > 2 seconds
Solution: Added Redis caching for predictions
Result: Reduced to < 200ms

docs.title: Challenge 4: Integration
docs.text:
Problem: Multiple systems didn't communicate
Solution: Created unified monitoring dashboard
Result: Single source of truth for all teams

docs.title: Do's
docs.text:
1. Start with a simple baseline before advanced models
  2. Invest heavily in data quality early
  3. Implement monitoring from day one
  4. Use version control for everything (code, data, models)
  5. Automate everything (CI/CD, training, deployment)

docs.title: Don'ts
docs.text:
1. Don't skip the EDA phase
  2. Don't deploy without monitoring
  3. Don't ignore feature engineering
  4. Don't overcomplicate the architecture initially
  5. Don't forget about security

docs.title: Temporal Features
docs.text:
python
# Time-based features
df['hour'] = df['datetime'].dt.hour
df['day'] = df['datetime'].dt.day
df['month'] = df['datetime'].dt.month
df['year'] = df['datetime'].dt.year
df['day_of_week'] = df['datetime'].dt.dayofweek
df['is_weekend'] = df['day_of_week'].isin([5, 6]).astype(int)

docs.title: Cyclical Features
docs.text:
python
# Cyclical encoding for periodicity
df['hour_sin'] = np.sin(2 * np.pi * df['hour'] / 24)
df['hour_cos'] = np.cos(2 * np.pi * df['hour'] / 24)
df['month_sin'] = np.sin(2 * np.pi * df['month'] / 12)
df['month_cos'] = np.cos(2 * np.pi * df['month'] / 12)

docs.title: Lag Features
docs.text:
python
# Historical lag features
df['lag_24h'] = df['total_load_actual'].shift(24)
df['lag_48h'] = df['total_load_actual'].shift(48)
df['lag_168h'] = df['total_load_actual'].shift(168)  # Weekly

docs.title: Rolling Statistics
docs.text:
python
# Rolling window features
df['rolling_mean_24h'] = df['total_load_actual'].rolling(24).mean()
df['rolling_std_24h'] = df['total_load_actual'].rolling(24).std()
df['rolling_mean_7d'] = df['total_load_actual'].rolling(168).mean()

docs.title: Outlier Detection
docs.text:
Method: IQR (Interquartile Range)
Formula: Outlier = value < Q1 - 1.5*IQR OR value > Q3 + 1.5*IQR

Results:
├── Temperature: 0.05% outliers → Capped at 3 std
├── Humidity: 0.02% outliers → Capped at 3 std
└── Energy Load: 0.1% outliers → Capped at 3 std

docs.title: GitHub Actions Workflow
docs.text:
yaml
name: ML Pipeline

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v4
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: |
          pip install -r requirements.txt
          pip install -r requirements_dev.txt

      - name: Run tests
        run: pytest tests/ --cov=src

      - name: Build Docker
        run: docker build -t energy-forecast:${{ github.sha }} .

      - name: Deploy to Staging
        if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'
        run: |
          kubectl set image deployment/api api=energy-forecast:${{ github.sha }}

docs.title: Business Problem
docs.text: Energy demand forecasting is critical for utility companies to: - Optimize power generation - Reduce energy wastage - Plan infrastructure investments - Minimize operational costs

docs.title: Challenge
docs.text: Traditional forecasting methods fail to capture: - Weather patterns impact on energy consumption - Time-based seasonality (daily, weekly, yearly) - Economic factors affecting demand

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: Build an ML-powered forecasting system that: 1. Predicts energy demand with >95% accuracy 2. Provides real-time predictions via API 3. Monitors model performance in production 4. Automates retraining when drift is detected

docs.text: Aspect Details Geographic Scope Regional energy grid Time Horizon Short-term (24-48 hours) Update Frequency Daily predictions Target Users Operations team, planners
